abstract.p: Inflation rate in Brazil rises to 7.67 percent in 2001 as currency, real, depreciates by 16 percent (S)

block.p: The inflation rate in Brazil rose to 7.67 percent in 2001 as a consequence of the wayward currency, the real, which depreciated by 16 percent last year. The government, which bases its monetary policy on inflation targets, set a maximum inflation ceiling of 6 percent last year, but an energy crisis and concern over the fitness of the economy in neighboring Argentina put pressure on the real. This year, the government has an inflation target of 3.5 percent, give or take two percentage points.
